pullRequest.body:
This PR is the final step in establishing the orthogonality relations for Dirichlet characters. 

See [here on Zulip](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/channel/144837-PR-reviews/topic/Orthogonality.20of.20Dirichlet.20characters/near/480747063).

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> Mathlib.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body:
### PR summary [edcf5596fd](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/18777/commits/edcf5596fd48f189fba8e446d62fd89c1fa1a373)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|
| `Mathlib.NumberTheory.DirichletCharacter.Orthogonality`|1600|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ card_eq_totient_of_hasEnoughRootsOfUnity`
`+ exists_apply_ne_one_of_hasEnoughRootsOfUnity`
`+ fintype`
`+ inv_mul_eq_one_of_isUnit`
`+ monoidHom_mulEquiv_of_hasEnoughRootsOfUnity`
`+ mulEquiv_units`
`+ sum_char_inv_mul_char_eq`
`+ sum_characters_eq`
`+ sum_characters_eq_zero`
`- mulEquiv_monoidHom_of_hasEnoughRootsOfUnity`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>
ðŸš€ Pull request has been placed on the maintainer queue by Ruben-VandeVelde.

Why do you assume throughout that there's a root of unity of order `n.totient`, and then derive the (strictly weaker) statement that you actually need, i.e. that there's a r.o.u. of order `((ZMod n)^x).exponent`, on-the-fly from this? I guess the answer is that the overwhelmingly most important use case is when `R` is the complex numbers and then you have roots of unity of all orders; and I don't want to hold up the progress of the wider project because of this detail. But it would be a pity if applications to e.g. rationality results for Dirichlet characters later get held up because nobody realises that the code in this file can be easily strengthened.

May I suggest we put in a TODO in the code, and a matching github issue, suggesting that in future it might be nice to implementing the  [Carmichael lambda function](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carmichael_function) and re-jig this code to require `HasEnoughRootsOfUnity R (carmichael_lambda n)` or some such? This would be a good first project for a learner.

If you think it makes sense to use the weaker hypothesis, I will do that. The main reason I used `n.totient` is that there appears to be no handy Mathlib name for [Carmichael's function](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carmichael_function). (Plus, as you say, I anticipated that this would mostly be used with algebraically closed fields as targets, where it doesn't really matter.)

> If you think it makes sense to use the weaker hypothesis, I will do that. The main reason I used `n.totient` is that there appears to be no handy Mathlib name for [Carmichael's function](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carmichael_function). (Plus, as you say, I anticipated that this would mostly be used with algebraically closed fields as targets, where it doesn't really matter.)

If the problem is only that the name is long to write you can always use a local notation or something. I agree it's not very important, but since it also comes at essentially zero cost I would go with David's suggestion.

Ii the end, it is only the `variable` line where one has to use the longer version, so that's not really a problem. Also, it saves a private lemma plus two proof lines, so I tink it is actually a good thing. Thanks @loefflerd !
I've also taken the opportunity of fixing an inconsistency in the direction of the isomorphism in one of the various duality statements (which also got rid of a few `.symm`s in the definitions).
This looks great now â€“Â the new treatment is both simpler and more general. Happy to recommend merging it in this form.

Thanks!

bors merge

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/11755993776/job/32751659201)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/11755993776/job/32751659283)
maintainer merge
maintainer merge

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat(NumberTheory/DirichletCharacter/Orthogonality): new file
